Yordan Tabov
Native name Bulgarian: Йордан Табов
Born 1946 (1946)
Sofia
Occupation mathematician
Nationality Bulgarian

Yordan Tabov (born in 1946 in Sofia) is a Bulgarian mathematician[1]with academic Degrees: Doctor of Pedagogical Sciences (2007), PhD in Mathematics (MGU, Moscow, 1974) [2] Besides he is also an amateur historian and supports the fringe views on the autochthonous origin of the Bulgarian people, espousing ideas similar to those of Gancho Tsenov.[3]

Contents

  • 1 Organizational activity
    • 1.1 Lecture:
    • 1.2 Participation in editorial choices:
  • 2 Selected works
  • 3 References

Organizational activity[edit]

  • Vice President of the International City Tournament (since 1990)
  • Member of the World Federation of Mathematical Race Awards (1992−1996) and (2000−2008)
  • Chairman of the Jury of the Chernorizets Hrabar Mathematical Tournament (since 1991)
  • Head of Mathematics and Informatics Training at IMI-BAS (1991−2008) [4]

Lecture:[edit]

Lectures at the Sofia University 1979−1989

Lectures at New Bulgarian University 1993−2009

Lectures at Bourgas Free University 1995−2003

Participation in editorial choices:[edit]

  •   Mathematics and Informatics (1984−2011)[5];[6]
  •   Indices of Mathematical Problems, Math Pro Press, USA (1994).[7]
  •   Mathematics Competitions Enrichment Series, AICME, Australia (1993)[8].
  •   Mathematics and Informatics Quarterly, SCT Publishing, Singapore (1991). (Editor-in-Chief 1991−2000) [9]
  • WENETS: Belogradchik Magazine for History, Culture and National Science. (2010)[10]

Selected works[edit]

  • J. Tabov. "A note on the five-circle theorem." Mathematics Magazine 63 (1989), 2, 92−94.[11]
  • J. Tabov, B. Lazarov. "Dialogue in Mathematical Correspondence by School Students." School Science and Mathematics 95:6 (1995), 327−329[12].
  • J. Tabov, P. Taylor. Methods of Problem Solving. Vol. 1. Australian Math. Trust, Belconnen, 1996. Vol. 2. 2002.[13]
  • J. Tabov. "Simple waves and simple states in R2." J. of Math. Anal. and Appl. 214 (1997) 613−632.[14]
  • J. Tabov, D. Kolev. "On the spread of simple waves in non-homogeneous media." Diff. Equations 34:6 (1998), 858. (In Russian)[15]
  • J. Tabov. "Formally integrable Mizohata systems in Rn. Fund. and Appl". Mathematics 5 (1999) 4, 1179−1189. (In Russian)[16]
  • J. Tabov. "Chronological Distribution of Information in Historical Texts." Computers and the Humanities, 37 (2003) 235−240.[17]
  • J. Tabov, E. Kelevedzhiev and B. Lazarov. "Multiple Choice Style Informatics." Mathematics Competitions, Vol. 16, 2003; 2, 60−69.[18]
  • J. Tabov, N. Todorov. "The 'archaic' inscription on the Big Stone Cross." Palaeobulgarica XXX (2006), 3, 88−99. (In Bulgarian)[19]
  • J. Tabov, N. Todorov. Cross with a Walachian inscription of "Zupan Kostadin"[20]. Palaeobulgarica XXXI (2007), 2, 76−82. (In Bulgarian)
  • S. Hristova, J. Tabov. Correlation of Two Chronological Distributions of the Extant Roman Bronze Coins. Review of the National Center for Digitization 12/2008 [21].
  • S. Hristova and J. Tabov. Chronological distribution of the Roman bronze coins. Storiadelmondo, n. 58, 15 July 2009. [22]
  • J. Tabov, S. Hristova and M. Dobreva, A Novel Comparative Study of the Dating of Bulgarian Parchment Manuscripts, In: QQML2009: Qualitative and Quantitative Methods in Libraries, International Conference, Chania Crete Greece, 26−29 May 2009, World Scientific , 2010, 489−494. [23]
  • V. Vachkova, J. Tabov. Helena of Sofia − a possible answer to the question why Sofia is "Constantine's Roma". Palaeobulgarica XXXII (2009), 4, 79−100. (In Bulgarian)[24]
  • J. Tabov, G. Panayotiva. Model of the dynamics of the coin circulation in the mediaeval Pliska. In: K. Markov, V. Velychko (editors). Applicable Information Models, No. 22. I T H E A, Sofia, 2011, 149−154. (In Russian) [25]http://www.foibg.com/ibs_isc/ibs-22/ibs-22-p21.pdf
  • J. Tabov. On the episcopate of Velika and some Bulgarian lands in the time of the kings Boris and Samuil. History, 2011, No. 5, 5−28. (In Bulgarian) [26]
